comments.text:
I'm Irish and I completely agree with The Young Turks. In fact when this 
headline came out two years ago, everyone I knew agreed that it was 
disturbing and utterly ridiculous that a woman died by being denied an 
abortion. The vast majority of Ireland, the middle aged to younger 
generation at least, feel oppressed by the Church-and-State archaic laws. 
We are literally right next to the UK yet we are 30 years behind them in 
terms of progression and the modern era. I love being Irish but in relation 
to Irish laws, I'm ashamed. I hate that we are known globally as being an 
uptight and oppressed nation who blindly follow the Church. The thing is 
that Ireland has become quite multinational in the past 10-15 years. Many 
people are born and raised Catholic, yes, but by parents who don't even 
practice the faith. In other words, Irish people are notoriously known for 
blindly following the religion that has oppressed and bullied us, and 
sexually assaulted our children, for the past 100 years. Do I believe in 
God? Yes. But the Catholic Church makes me sick. I was "raised a Catholic" 
because if you didn't baptize your child back in 1993, well firstly you 
couldn't have gotten into any school, and secondly you would pretty much be 
disowned by your family. I made the sacraments, communion, confession and 
confirmation through no choice of my own but through my primary school's 
rules. My family and I are now proudly ex Catholics. And if/when I have 
children, I'll be damned if I get them baptized as babies against their own 
will or take them to a judgmental church on Sundays. Irish people put down 
in writing that they're Catholic, but every year, fewer and fewer regularly 
attend Church. It makes me sick to be part of a nation dominated by 
religion and appallingly disgusting laws.﻿

+Jacob Brunberg I can't believe I'm getting sucked into this, especially 
since your  replies to my points are so inane and are clearly borne 
entirely of your own emotional response rather than logic and facts, but 
here I go:
1) forcing someone to go through a pregnancy against their will as a 
punishment for a mistake is not only stupid but cruel. ESPECIALLY since 
it's an outside force (people like you) enforcing said punishment. 
Pregnancies can do a lot of damage to a woman's body. 
2) You clearly don't understand that this isn't the Hand Maids Tale as you 
feel entitled to dictate what medical decisions a woman may or may not make 
with her doctor- and your views are entirely based on your belief that a 
cystoblast/zygote/fetus is the same as child- a view not shared by either 
the medical profession or the government, or the vast majority of people 
for that matter- otherwise you'd be able to claim it on your taxes, and 
there wouldn't be terms like cystoblast/zygote or fetus-doctors would just 
say "child" or "infant". Beyond that, when someone is pregnant and already 
has 2 kids, have you ever heard someone say I have 3 kids? Why do we say 
people are "expecting" when they're pregnant as opposed to" they have a 
kid"? Why is IVF still legal? If a woman miscarries should there be an 
inquest? 
3) This is not tricky at all- you either believe you have the right to 
force a girl or a woman to give birth against her will or you don't. You 
clearly feel that you have that right. I'll admit this last one is 
particularly emotional for me, but it's still true. 
You can reply if you wish,but I have a massive amount of work to do.

elective abortion at 9 months, I ignore because that's not me. I get all 
kinds of insults just for being pro-choice. I get called a horrible baby 
killing slut that needs to stop having so much sex with so many people. 
Even though I'm infertile and in a committed marriage with another woman.

If you are fine with abortion in the case of an incomplete miscarriage 
great. However, there are pro-lifers without exceptions that are not and 
those people are the most vocal, and they are the ones that make laws, and 
that's who Cenk who is talking about, not people like yourself. It doesn't 
sound like he's talking about you.

Oh and the doctors aren't dumb. A lot of these laws with a mother's health 
exception are very vague. Ohio has passed HB 78 in 2011, which is a 20 week 
ban that contains a exception for the mother's life in danger or if the 
mother is at risk of a major bodily impairment, but yet it doesn't really 
cite that many specifics. Sponsors of this bill were asked why it wasn't 
clearer and asked for clarity and the sponsor couldn't clarify what 
mother's life in danger or severe, bodily impairment meant. I bet the 
Ireland law was and still is the same way and possibly still is. To violate 
these bills means loss of a doctor's medical license, fines, and lots of 
time in jail. Doctors play it safe instead of risk breaking a very vague 
law. It's understandable. That was the objection of a lot of OB/GYNs in 
Ohio, who spoke at the 2011 HB 78 hearings. That they would leave, because 
the law was too vague and didn't want to risk loss of their medical 
license, fines, and time in jail or prison.
